results.headline: Iraqi Insurgents, in Their Own Words

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Meeting Resistance

results.summary_short: If nothing else, “Meeting Resistance” should dispel any lingering misconception that the Iraq insurgency is mainly the work of outside agitators.

results.headline: A Rampage That Shook New Zealand
results.display_title: Out of the Blue: A Film About Life and Football at Boise State

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Out of the Blue: A Film About Life and Football at Boise State

results.summary_short: “Out of the Blue,” by the writer and director Robert Sarkies, dramatizes the terror of a day of massacre without exploiting it.

results.headline: A Collector and His Polaroid Passions
results.display_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe

results.summary_short: James Crump’s documentary is a potent exercise in art-world mythography that might be nicknamed “The Prince and the Punk.”

results.headline: Sometimes in the Woods, Hunters Become the Hunted

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trigger Man

results.summary_short: Devised for minimum fuss and maximum tension, “Trigger Man” is the little thriller that could.

results.headline: Tumbleweeds, Sagebrush and Kielbasa on the Range

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dead Man's Bounty

results.summary_short: “Summer Love” has been called the first Polish western and the first Polish spaghetti western, though the truer description might be the first deconstructed art western.

results.headline: Portrait of a Ladies’ Man

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Klimt

results.summary_short: John Malkovich has virtually cornered the market on portraying aesthetes in the thrall of demonic visions. “Klimt” adds to his gallery of elegant monsters.

results.headline: Carefully Taking a Cool Look at a Topic That’s Always Hot

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of O Jerusalem

results.summary_short: It’s not easy to turn one of the most controversial events of the 20th century into a movie that makes your eyes roll, but “O Jerusalem” does this and worse.

results.headline: Four Couples Gather to Ask One Question: Can’t We All Just Get Along?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Why Did I Get Married?

results.summary_short: Couched in a familiar language of hope and redemption, “Tyler Perry’s Why Did I Get Married?” benefits from one of the strongest casts of Tyler Perry’s career.

results.headline: She’s Fallen but Not Down

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Laaga Chunari Mein Daag

results.summary_short: A fascinating blend of musical, melodrama and feminist fairy tale, “Laaga Chunari Mein Daag” shows Bollywood’s moral universe in transition.

results.headline: Building a Case Against the Worldly Lawyer to the Notorious

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Terror's Advocate

results.summary_short: “Terror’s Advocate” is one of the most engaging, morally unsettling political thrillers in quite some time, with the extra advantage of being true.

results.headline: A Dance of Two Men, Twisting and Turning With a Gun That’s More Than a Gun

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sleuth

results.summary_short: In the remake of “Sleuth,” what was once insignificant is now insufferable.

results.headline: 2 Brothers, and the Mob in the Middle

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Own the Night

results.summary_short: “We Own the Night” is a bloody, passionate melodrama, self-consciously Shakespearean — or Biblical, or Greek, take your pick of atavisms — in its intentions.

results.headline: Swinging Singers

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Naked Boys Singing!

results.summary_short: In “Naked Boys Singing!” 10 grown men (including one natural redhead) go full monty while belting out show tunes and high-kicking like muscular Rockettes.

results.headline: A Lonely Guy Plays House With a Mail-Order Sex Doll

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lars and the Real Girl

results.summary_short: “Lars and the Real Girl” is part comedy, part tragedy and 100 percent pure calculation.

results.headline: Ecological and Religious Dimensions

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Khadak

results.summary_short: Eerie, muddled and gorgeous, “Khadak” tells the story of an epileptic Mongolian sheepherder who embraces his destiny as a shaman when his village is threatened.

results.headline: Now, Warrior

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Elizabeth: The Golden Age

results.summary_short: “Elizabeth: The Golden Age” is a kitsch extravaganza aquiver with trembling bosoms, booming guns and wild energy.

results.headline: Lost in the Maize

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of King Corn

results.summary_short: “King Corn” is a gentle, meandering entry in the Truth-Seeking Comic Hero genre, as practiced by Michael Moore and Morgan Spurlock.

results.headline: Illness Rends One Mind, Three Hearts

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Canvas

results.summary_short: “Canvas” is a movie that rings emotionally true, despite structural contrivances and dim, washed-out color.

results.headline: Haunting Songs of Heartbreak, Done by a Man With Experience

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Control

results.summary_short: Where “Control” might have been literal-minded and sentimental, it is instead enigmatic and moving, much in the manner of Joy Division’s best songs.

results.headline: A Formidable Legacy and a Heavy Heart

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Golda's Balcony

results.summary_short: What happens when idealism becomes power? That question is the driving force of Jeremy Kagan’s inert yet strangely compelling film “Golda’s Balcony.”
